title: Epic 7: Fix Broken Links and Content Issues
description:
## Summary
Resolve all broken links and content issues identified during the documentation audit. This includes GitBook orphan page references, absolute GitBook editor URLs, and anchor ID mismatches.

## Context
This project is a Next.js + Markdoc documentation site in the `documentation/` directory. The content was migrated from GitBook. By the time this epic runs, Epic 3 (Content Migration) has moved all files into `documentation/pages/` and done initial cleanup. However, some broken links may remain that require human judgment to resolve.

All content files are now in `documentation/pages/` (not the old root-level locations). Internal links should use paths without `.md` extensions.

## Broken Links Inventory

### Category 1: GitBook Orphan Page References (3 instances)
When GitBook exports to Git, internal cross-references that fail to resolve become `/broken/pages/XXXXX` links. These need to be resolved or removed.

| File (post-migration path) | Broken Link | Context |
|---|---|---|
| `pages/index.md` | `/broken/pages/gNQzZ9R1b3NKrJoQ0Iqa` | Read the surrounding text to determine what this was supposed to link to. It's on the landing/welcome page. |
| `pages/lexicons/introduction-to-lexicons.md` | `/broken/pages/3UwgsMpD20ErXurhzmTh` | Read the surrounding text -- likely links to one of the lexicon pages |
| `pages/lexicons/introduction-to-lexicons.md` | `/broken/pages/FdVczwFhTBj7n5nszh0P` | Read the surrounding text -- likely links to one of the lexicon pages |

**Resolution approach:**
1. Open each file and read the surrounding text around the broken link
2. Infer what page the link was supposed to point to based on the link text and context
3. If the target can be determined (e.g., "General Lexicons" probably links to `/lexicons/general-lexicons`), replace with the correct path
4. If the target cannot be determined, remove the `[text](/broken/pages/...)` link syntax but keep the text as plain text. Add a `<!-- TODO: broken link from GitBook migration -->` HTML comment

### Category 2: Absolute GitBook Editor URL (1 instance)
| File | Broken Link |
|---|---|
| `pages/lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons/activity-claim.md` | `https://app.gitbook.com/o/uxU8o4s6mrp88yBisLn5/s/8dkOAon1uQbyqL8RomaJ/hypercert-claim-lexicons/the-impact-and-work-space` |

**Resolution:** The URL path ends with `the-impact-and-work-space`. Replace with the relative internal link `/getting-started/the-impact-and-work-space`.

### Category 3: Anchor ID Mismatches (2 instances)
| File | Link | Problem | Fix |
|---|---|---|---|
| `pages/getting-started/the-impact-and-work-space.md` | Self-referencing `#the-impact-space` | No heading with this anchor exists in the file | Read the file to find the closest matching heading and fix the anchor. If no heading matches, remove the link. |
| `pages/lexicons/general-lexicons/location.md` | Self-referencing `#locationtype` | The heading is "### Location Type" which generates anchor `#location-type` (hyphenated) | Change `#locationtype` to `#location-type` |

## Verification Steps
After fixing all links, run these checks:
```bash
# Check for any remaining GitBook artifacts
grep -r '/broken/pages/' documentation/pages/
grep -r 'app.gitbook.com' documentation/pages/

# Should all return zero results
```

Also manually verify:
- Open each fixed link in the dev server to confirm it navigates correctly
- For anchor links, click them and verify they scroll to the correct heading

## Acceptance Criteria
- All 3 `/broken/pages/...` links are either resolved to correct internal paths or removed (text preserved)
- The absolute GitBook editor URL in activity-claim.md is replaced with `/getting-started/the-impact-and-work-space`
- Both anchor mismatches are fixed to point to valid heading IDs
- `grep -r '/broken/' documentation/pages/` returns zero results
- `grep -r 'app.gitbook.com' documentation/pages/` returns zero results
- All fixed links work when tested in the browser via `npm run dev`

title: Epic 4: Navigation and Layout System
description:
## Summary
Build a three-column page layout and programmatic navigation system to replace GitBook's `SUMMARY.md`-based navigation. The layout should follow the design language used by Stripe's documentation (docs.stripe.com): a left sidebar for navigation, a centered content column, and a right-side table of contents with scroll spy.

## Context
This project is a Next.js + Markdoc documentation site in the `documentation/` directory. GitBook uses a file called `SUMMARY.md` with nested Markdown lists to define navigation. We need to replace this with React components.

By the time this epic runs:
- Epic 1 has scaffolded the Next.js project
- `pages/_app.js` exists and wraps all pages
- Content `.md` files are in `pages/` (from Epic 3)

### Current SUMMARY.md navigation structure:
```markdown
# Table of contents
* [Welcome to the Hypercerts Protocol](README.md)
## Getting Started
* [Why we're building Hypercerts](getting-started/why-were-building-hypercerts.md)
* [Introduction to Impact Claims](getting-started/introduction-to-impact-claims.md)
* [The Impact and Work Space](getting-started/the-impact-and-work-space.md)
* [The Hypercerts Infrastructure](getting-started/the-hypercerts-infrastructure.md)
* [Installing the SDK](getting-started/installing-the-sdk.md)
## Lexicons
* [Introduction to Lexicons](lexicons/introduction-to-lexicons.md)
* [General Lexicons](lexicons/general-lexicons/README.md)
  * [Shared Defs](lexicons/general-lexicons/shared-defs.md)
  * [Location](lexicons/general-lexicons/location.md)
* [Hypercerts Lexicons](lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons/README.md)
  * [Activity Claim](lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons/activity-claim.md)
  * [Contribution](lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons/contribution.md)
  * [Evaluation](lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons/evaluation.md)
  * [Measurement](lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons/measurement.md)
  * [Attachment](lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons/attachment.md)
  * [Rights](lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons/rights.md)
  * [Collection](lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons/collection.md)
---
* [Deep Dive: The Work Scope](deep-dive-the-work-scope.md)
```

## Design Language (Stripe-Inspired)

The layout should follow these Stripe documentation patterns:

### Three-column layout:
```
┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│  Header: Site title + optional search                     │
├────────────┬──────────────────────────────┬───────────────┤
│            │                              │               │
│  Left      │  Main Content                │  Right TOC    │
│  Sidebar   │  (max-width ~720px)          │  (~200px)     │
│  (~240px)  │                              │               │
│            │                              │  - Section 1  │
│  Section   │  # Page Title                │  - Section 2  │
│  Header    │                              │  - Section 3  │
│  ├─ Link   │  Body text...                │               │
│  ├─ Link   │                              │               │
│  └─ Link   │  ## Section 1                │               │
│            │  More text...                 │               │
│  Section   │                              │               │
│  Header    │  ## Section 2                │               │
│  ├─ Link   │  Even more text...           │               │
│  └─ Link   │                              │               │
│            │  ┌─────────┬──────────┐      │               │
│            │  │ ← Prev  │ Next →   │      │               │
│            │  └─────────┴──────────┘      │               │
├────────────┴──────────────────────────────┴───────────────┤
```

### Visual characteristics:
- **Background**: Pure white (#ffffff) everywhere
- **Sidebar**: 240px wide, sticky/fixed position, scrolls independently. Right border: 1px solid #ebeef1 (very subtle gray)
- **Content area**: Max-width ~720px, centered in the remaining space with padding 32px on each side
- **Right TOC**: ~200px wide, sticky, shows H2-level headings from current page, highlights current section as user scrolls (scroll spy)
- **Section headers in sidebar**: Small text, semibold (font-weight 600), uppercase or regular case, color #687385 (secondary gray). NOT clickable -- they are category labels
- **Nav items in sidebar**: Regular weight (400), color #414552 (dark gray). On hover: slight background tint. Active item: bold text (600) + light blue-gray background tint
- **Nesting**: One level of indent for child pages (e.g., "Shared Defs" indented under "General Lexicons")
- **Pagination**: Previous/Next links at the bottom of content area, styled as a flex row with left/right alignment

## What You Need to Create

### 1. Navigation config -- `lib/navigation.js`
```js
export const navigation = [
  { title: 'Welcome', path: '/' },
  {
    section: 'Getting Started',
    children: [
      { title: "Why We're Building Hypercerts", path: '/getting-started/why-were-building-hypercerts' },
      { title: 'Introduction to Impact Claims', path: '/getting-started/introduction-to-impact-claims' },
      { title: 'The Impact and Work Space', path: '/getting-started/the-impact-and-work-space' },
      { title: 'The Hypercerts Infrastructure', path: '/getting-started/the-hypercerts-infrastructure' },
      { title: 'Installing the SDK', path: '/getting-started/installing-the-sdk' },
    ]
  },
  {
    section: 'Lexicons',
    children: [
      { title: 'Introduction to Lexicons', path: '/lexicons/introduction-to-lexicons' },
      {
        title: 'General Lexicons',
        path: '/lexicons/general-lexicons',
        children: [
          { title: 'Shared Defs', path: '/lexicons/general-lexicons/shared-defs' },
          { title: 'Location', path: '/lexicons/general-lexicons/location' },
        ]
      },
      {
        title: 'Hypercerts Lexicons',
        path: '/lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons',
        children: [
          { title: 'Activity Claim', path: '/lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons/activity-claim' },
          { title: 'Contribution', path: '/lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons/contribution' },
          { title: 'Evaluation', path: '/lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons/evaluation' },
          { title: 'Measurement', path: '/lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons/measurement' },
          { title: 'Evidence', path: '/lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons/attachment' },
          { title: 'Rights', path: '/lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons/rights' },
          { title: 'Collection', path: '/lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons/collection' },
        ]
      }
    ]
  },
  { title: 'Deep Dive: The Work Scope', path: '/deep-dive-the-work-scope' },
];
```

Items with `section` are non-clickable category headers. Items with `path` are clickable nav links. Items with `children` can be expanded/collapsed.

### 2. Sidebar component -- `components/Sidebar.js`
- Renders the navigation tree recursively
- Uses `next/router` to detect the current path and highlight the active item
- Section headers rendered as non-clickable labels (semibold, secondary gray, small text)
- Active item gets bold weight + subtle background highlight
- Child items are indented ~16px from their parent
- Collapsible groups: items with children auto-expand when any child is active
- On mobile (< 768px): sidebar is hidden, revealed via a hamburger toggle button

### 3. Table of Contents component -- `components/TableOfContents.js`
- Extracts H2 (and optionally H3) headings from the page content
- Renders a list of anchor links on the right side
- Implements scroll spy: highlights the heading currently in view as the user scrolls
- Sticky positioning: stays in view as user scrolls the content
- Heading text in small font (13px), secondary gray color, active heading in dark color

To extract headings, you can parse `pageProps.markdoc.content` (the Markdoc AST) or use a client-side approach that queries the DOM for `h2` elements after render.

### 4. Layout component -- `components/Layout.js`
- Wraps all pages with the three-column layout
- Accepts `frontmatter` (from `pageProps.markdoc.frontmatter`) and `children`
- Renders: Header, Sidebar, Main Content, TableOfContents
- Header: simple bar with site title "Hypercerts Protocol" on the left, minimal height (~56px), bottom border 1px #ebeef1
- Main content area: the `children` prop, wrapped in an `<article>` tag
- Pagination: prev/next links at the bottom, derived from the flat list of navigation items

### 5. Update `pages/_app.js`
```jsx
import '../styles/globals.css';
import Layout from '../components/Layout';
// ... component imports for Markdoc tags

export default function App({ Component, pageProps }) {
  return (
    <Layout frontmatter={pageProps.markdoc?.frontmatter}>
      <Component {...pageProps} />
    </Layout>
  );
}
```

### 6. Helper: Flatten navigation for prev/next
Create a utility function that flattens the navigation tree into an ordered array of `{ title, path }` objects. This is used to compute previous/next page links based on the current path.

## Acceptance Criteria
- `lib/navigation.js` exports the full navigation tree matching the SUMMARY.md structure
- `components/Sidebar.js` renders the tree with section headers, active highlighting, and nesting
- `components/TableOfContents.js` renders right-side H2 anchors with scroll spy
- `components/Layout.js` implements the three-column layout with header, sidebar, content, and TOC
- `pages/_app.js` wraps all pages in the Layout component
- Current page is highlighted in the sidebar
- Prev/next pagination works at the bottom of each page
- Layout is responsive: sidebar and TOC collapse/hide on mobile (< 768px), hamburger menu reveals sidebar
- Page title from frontmatter is displayed in the header or as the page `<title>`
- `SUMMARY.md` is no longer needed for navigation (can be deleted in the cleanup epic)

title: Epic 1: Scaffold Next.js + Markdoc Project
description:
## Summary
Set up a Next.js project with Markdoc integration inside the existing `documentation/` directory. This is the foundation that all other migration work depends on. The final documentation site should follow a Stripe-docs-inspired design language (clean, white, professional, content-focused).

## Current State of the Repository
The repository root is at `/Users/sharfy/Code/hypercerts-atproto-documentation`. Inside it:
- `documentation/` -- contains the current documentation (a GitBook-managed site with NO build toolchain, NO package.json)
- `.beads/` -- beads issue tracker database (do not modify)
- `AGENTS.md` -- agent instructions (do not modify)

The `documentation/` directory currently contains:
```
documentation/
├── .gitbook/
│   └── assets/
│       ├── hypercert erd.png
│       └── hypercerts_for_projects.png
├── README.md                    (landing page)
├── SUMMARY.md                   (GitBook navigation config)
├── deep-dive-the-work-scope.md
├── getting-started/
│   ├── why-were-building-hypercerts.md
│   ├── introduction-to-impact-claims.md
│   ├── the-impact-and-work-space.md
│   ├── the-hypercerts-infrastructure.md
│   └── installing-the-sdk.md
└── lexicons/
    ├── introduction-to-lexicons.md
    ├── general-lexicons/
    │   ├── README.md
    │   ├── shared-defs.md
    │   └── location.md
    └── hypercerts-lexicons/
        ├── README.md
        ├── activity-claim.md
        ├── contribution.md
        ├── evaluation.md
        ├── measurement.md
        ├── attachment.md
        ├── rights.md
        └── collection.md
```

That's 17 Markdown content files, 1 navigation file (SUMMARY.md), and 2 PNG images. There is no package.json, no JavaScript, no build toolchain.

## What You Need to Do

### 1. Initialize the Next.js project inside `documentation/`
Run these commands from inside the `documentation/` directory:
```bash
npm init -y
npm install next@latest react@latest react-dom@latest @markdoc/markdoc @markdoc/next.js
```

### 2. Create `next.config.js`
```js
const withMarkdoc = require('@markdoc/next.js');

module.exports = withMarkdoc({ mode: 'static' })({
  pageExtensions: ['md', 'mdoc', 'js', 'jsx', 'ts', 'tsx']
});
```

### 3. Add scripts to `package.json`
```json
{
  "scripts": {
    "dev": "next dev",
    "build": "next build",
    "start": "next start"
  }
}
```

### 4. Create the directory structure
Create these empty directories (content will be added in later epics):
```
documentation/
├── components/          # React components (Layout, Sidebar, etc.)
├── markdoc/
│   ├── tags/            # Custom Markdoc tag definitions
│   └── nodes/           # Custom Markdoc node overrides
├── pages/               # Next.js pages (content .md files go here)
│   └── _app.js          # App wrapper
├── public/
│   └── images/          # Static assets (images)
├── styles/
│   └── globals.css      # Global stylesheet
├── next.config.js
├── package.json
└── .gitignore
```

### 5. Create `pages/_app.js`
A minimal app wrapper that imports global styles:
```jsx
import '../styles/globals.css';

export default function App({ Component, pageProps }) {
  return <Component {...pageProps} />;
}
```
Note: The Layout component wrapping will be added in Epic 4 (Navigation & Layout). For now, just the bare wrapper is needed.

### 6. Create a minimal `styles/globals.css`
Just enough to verify the site loads:
```css
* { box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0; padding: 0; }
body { font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; }
```

### 7. Create a test page at `pages/index.md`
```markdown
---
title: Test Page
---

# Hello Markdoc

This is a test page to verify the setup works.
```

### 8. Create `.gitignore`
```
node_modules/
.next/
out/
```

### 9. Verify
```bash
npm run dev    # Should start at http://localhost:3000
npm run build  # Should complete without errors
```

After verifying, you can delete the test `pages/index.md` -- it will be replaced by actual content in Epic 3.

## Acceptance Criteria
- `documentation/package.json` exists with next, react, react-dom, @markdoc/markdoc, @markdoc/next.js as dependencies
- `documentation/next.config.js` exists with `withMarkdoc({ mode: 'static' })` and `pageExtensions: ['md', 'mdoc', 'js', 'jsx', 'ts', 'tsx']`
- Directory structure has: `pages/`, `components/`, `markdoc/`, `markdoc/tags/`, `markdoc/nodes/`, `public/`, `public/images/`, `styles/` directories
- `pages/_app.js` exists with a basic wrapper that imports globals.css
- `styles/globals.css` exists with minimal reset
- `npm run dev` starts the dev server successfully and shows the test page
- `npm run build` completes without errors
- `.gitignore` includes node_modules/, .next/, out/
- The existing GitBook files (README.md, SUMMARY.md, getting-started/, lexicons/, .gitbook/, deep-dive-the-work-scope.md) are NOT deleted or moved yet -- that happens in later epics

title: Epic 8: Build Configuration and Vercel Deployment
description:
## Summary
Verify the Next.js build pipeline works end-to-end, fix any build errors, and configure Vercel deployment for the documentation site.

## Context
This project is a Next.js + Markdoc documentation site in the `documentation/` directory inside the repository at `/Users/sharfy/Code/hypercerts-atproto-documentation/documentation/`. All commands should be run from the `documentation/` directory.

By the time this epic runs, Epics 1-7 have:
- Scaffolded the Next.js + Markdoc project (Epic 1)
- Created custom Markdoc tags and React components (Epic 2)
- Migrated all 17 content files to `pages/` (Epic 3)
- Built the navigation and layout system (Epic 4)
- Applied Stripe-inspired styling (Epic 5)
- Moved images to `public/images/` (Epic 6)
- Fixed all broken links (Epic 7)

## Tasks

### 1. Verify Local Development Server
```bash
cd documentation
npm run dev
```
- Open http://localhost:3000 in a browser
- Navigate through ALL pages via the sidebar and verify:
  - Pages load without console errors
  - Images display correctly
  - Tables render with proper styling
  - Callout boxes display with colored left borders
  - Column layouts work (side by side on desktop)
  - Sidebar navigation highlights the current page
  - Right-side table of contents shows headings
  - Prev/next pagination links work
- Fix any runtime errors or warnings

### 2. Verify Production Build
```bash
cd documentation
npm run build
```
- Ensure the build completes with ZERO errors
- Common issues to watch for:
  - Missing component imports
  - Invalid Markdoc tag syntax in .md files
  - Broken internal links that cause 404s during static generation
  - CSS module import errors
- Fix any build-time errors before proceeding

### 3. Test Production Server Locally
```bash
cd documentation
npm run start
```
- Verify the production build serves correctly at http://localhost:3000
- Spot-check 3-5 pages for rendering issues
- Verify images load (they should be in `public/images/`)

### 4. Configure Static Export (if desired)
For pure static hosting, add `output: 'export'` to `next.config.js`:
```js
const withMarkdoc = require('@markdoc/next.js');
module.exports = withMarkdoc({ mode: 'static' })({
  output: 'export',
  pageExtensions: ['md', 'mdoc', 'js', 'jsx', 'ts', 'tsx']
});
```
Then `npm run build` will output static files to the `out/` directory.

### 5. Verify .gitignore
Ensure `documentation/.gitignore` contains:
```
node_modules/
.next/
out/
```

### 6. Prepare for Vercel Deployment
Create or verify that the project is ready for Vercel:
- The `documentation/` directory should be self-contained with its own `package.json`
- `npm run build` must succeed
- The Vercel project settings should be:
  - **Root Directory:** `documentation`
  - **Framework Preset:** Next.js (auto-detected)
  - **Build Command:** `npm run build` (or auto-detected)
  - **Output Directory:** `.next` (or `out` if using static export)

Note: Actually connecting the GitHub repo to Vercel and deploying is a manual step that requires Vercel account access. This epic should ensure the project is deployment-ready.

## Acceptance Criteria
- `npm run dev` starts without errors and all 17 pages render correctly
- `npm run build` completes with zero errors
- `npm run start` serves the production build correctly
- `.gitignore` excludes `node_modules/`, `.next/`, `out/`
- All pages, images, tables, callouts, columns, sidebar navigation, and pagination work correctly
- The project is ready to be deployed to Vercel (self-contained `documentation/` directory with valid `package.json` and build scripts)

title: Epic 3: Content Migration - Convert All 17 Markdown Files
description:
## Summary Convert all 17 GitBook Markdown files to Markdoc-compatible format and move them into the Next.js `pages/` directory. This involves replacing GitBook-proprietary syntax with Markdoc tags, cleaning up HTML artifacts, fixing frontmatter, and restructuring file paths for Next.js routing. ## Context This project is a Next.js + Markdoc documentation site in the `documentation/` directory at the repo root (`/Users/sharfy/Code/hypercerts-atproto-documentation/documentation/`). The current GitBook content files are at the `documentation/` root level (e.g., `documentation/README.md`, `documentation/getting-started/why-were-building-hypercerts.md`). They need to be moved into `documentation/pages/` for Next.js file-based routing. By the time this epic runs: - Epic 1 (Scaffold) has created the `pages/`, `components/`, `markdoc/`, etc. directories - Epic 2 (Custom Tags) has created Markdoc tags: `{% callout %}`, `{% columns %}`,
